Name: Markers for ‘specific known’
Description: The referent is specific and known to the speaker (e.g. ‘I met someone yesterday at the workshop. We agreed to meet again tomorrow.’)

Name: Markers for ‘specific unknown’
Description: The referent is specific but not known to the speaker (e.g. ‘Unfortunately, I lost my purse somewhere in the shopping centre.’)

Name: Markers for ‘irrealis non-specific’
Description: The referent is non-specific, occurring only in some imagined mental space (e.g. ‘I hope that I will meet someone nice at the party.’)

Name: Markers for ‘question’
Description: The indefinite pronoun occurs in a question (e.g. ‘Did you meet someone interesting at the workshop?’)

Name: Markers for ‘conditional’
Description: The indefinite pronoun occurs in a subordinate conditional clause (e.g. ‘If you meet someone interesting at the workshop, you will be lucky.’)

Name: Markers for ‘indirect negation’
Description: The indefinite pronoun is in the scope of negation, but not of the same clause (e.g. ‘I do not expect that any of our friends will be there.’)

Name: Markers for ‘direct negation’
Description: The indefinite pronoun is in the scope of negation within the same clause (e.g. ‘I did not meet any of our friends there.’)

Name: Markers for ‘comparative’
Description: The indefinite pronoun occurs in the standard of a comparative construction (e.g. ‘Our guest was more interesting than any of our old friends.’)

Name: Markers for ‘free choice’
Description: The indefinite pronoun indicates free choice (e.g. ‘Anyone can come to my birthday party, and they can bring anything’.)
